item.title: Scanning a network to find a Kubernetes api server
item.description: Morpheus Neo, there's a Kubernetes api server available somewhere in 192.168.99.0/24, you have to find it to reach the pods. Neo That's 256 addresses, how am I supposed to guess the right one?! Morpheus I'm trying to free your mind, Neo. But I can only show you the door. You're the one that has to walk through it.

item.title: Deploy traefik in GKE using (L7) Google HTTP/S Load balancer
item.description: Using Google Load Balancers in GKE Google Cloud proposes multiple types of load balancers and we can use those in GKE. Usually, the first thing we do in GKE when we need to expose a service is to set its type to type: LoadBalancer. Under the hood, GCP automatically creates a Regional External TCP/UDP Network Load Balancer (L4) that gives us an IP address in Kubernetes to reach our service.
